maml:description.maml:para: Basic way to output a markdown table.

Basic way to output a markdown table. Doesn't support much and has issues with constructing huge tables (get-process). It relies mainly on ConvertTo-Csv, then tweaks the output to turn it into a markdown table.

maml:alert.maml:para: Needed a quick way of copying PowerShell output to Markdown notes. I found Markdown tables were a bit nicer than doing backtick code blocks in some cases. Will likely switch to Markdig Markdown at some point.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Item C:\temp | Select-Object mode,lastwritetime,length,name| ConvertTo-MarkDownTable |Mode|LastWriteTime|length|Name| |---|---|---|---| |d----|4/30/2022 1:26:44 PM||Temp|

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the object to a MarkDownTable

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Get-Item C:\temp | Select-Object mode,lastwritetime,length,name| ConvertTo-MarkDownTable | clip |Mode|LastWriteTime|length|Name| |---|---|---|---| |d----|4/30/2022 1:26:44 PM||Temp|

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the object to a MarkDownTable and places it on the clipboard.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $output = Get-Item C:\temp | Select-Object mode,lastwritetime,length,name PS C:\> ConvertTo-MarkDownTable $output |Mode|LastWriteTime|length|Name| |---|---|---|---| |d----|4/30/2022 1:26:44 PM||Temp|

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the object to a MarkDownTable
